bibl.title: Letter from Robert P. Cooke to Philip Showalter Hench, [September 4, 1940]

div1.p: Cooke writes that he would be glad to look over Hench's memorandum on the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Robert P. Cooke to Philip Showalter Hench, [September 4, 1940]
div1.opener:
undated
Received about Sept 4, 1940 COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA
STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
LEXINGTON-ROCKBRIDGE HEALTH DEPARTMENT
LEXINGTON, VIRGINIA
Dr Philip S. Hench
Rochester Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of Aug 26 th is acknowledged and I
shall be glad to look over your memorandum and
help you in any way I can in connection with
your paper on the work of the Reed commission

I'm sorry I have no photographs of the buildings
and doubt if I could locate the Camp were I
in Havana. In a long time ago. There are some
good illustrations of the buildings in Dr Howard
Kelleys' book “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”
I never have written any story of my rather minor
part in this proceedings
COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA
STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
LEXINGTON-ROCKBRIDGE HEALTH DEPARTMENT
LEXINGTON, VIRGINIA
and doubt if I have the literary talent to produce
anything interesting- John H Andrus 805 Cooper St
Camden N. J. was one of the experiments squad and
was given “the works” to use a common expression
mosquitoes serum etc. He is now an invalid, some type,
of myelitis but has written an account of his personal
experience which he will, no doubt be glad to send
you. Dr Geo B. Lawson Room [?], Med Arts Bldg
has visited Havana in recent years and is much
interested in everything that concerns Reed's discovery.

If I can be of any help to you don't hesitate
to call on me.
